member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.EnhancedStackFrame.GetILOffset
member.summary: Gets the offset from the start of the Microsoft intermediate language (MSIL) code for the method that is executing. This offset might be an approximation depending on whether or not the just-in-time (JIT) compiler is generating debugging code. The generation of this debugging information is controlled by the System.Diagnostics.DebuggableAttribute.
member.returns: The offset from the start of the MSIL code for the method that is executing.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.EnhancedStackFrame.GetMethod
member.summary: Gets the method in which the frame is executing.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.EnhancedStackFrame.GetNativeOffset
member.summary: Gets the offset from the start of the native just-in-time (JIT)-compiled code for the method that is being executed. The generation of this debugging information is controlled by the System.Diagnostics.DebuggableAttribute class.
member.returns: The offset from the start of the JIT-compiled code for the method that is being executed.

member.name: T:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism
member.remarks: The exception mechanism is an optional field residing in the Exception Interface. It carries additional information about the way the exception was created on the target system. This includes general exception values obtained from operating system or runtime APIs, as well as mechanism-specific values.

member.name: F:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.HandledKey
member.summary: Keys found inside of the Exception Dictionary to inform if the exception was handled and which mechanism tracked it.

member.name: F:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.MechanismKey
member.summary: Key found inside of the Exception.Data to inform if the exception which mechanism tracked it.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Type
member.summary: Required unique identifier of this mechanism determining rendering and processing of the mechanism data.
member.remarks: The type attribute is required to send any exception mechanism attribute, even if the SDK cannot determine the specific mechanism. In this case, set the type to "generic". See below for an example.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Description
member.summary: Optional human readable description of the error mechanism and a possible hint on how to solve this error.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.HelpLink
member.summary: Optional fully qualified URL to an online help resource, possible interpolated with error parameters.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Handled
member.summary: Optional flag indicating whether the exception has been handled by the user (e.g. via try..catch).

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Meta
member.summary: Optional information from the operating system or runtime on the exception mechanism.
member.remarks: The mechanism meta data usually carries error codes reported by the runtime or operating system, along with a platform dependent interpretation of these codes. SDKs can safely omit code names and descriptions for well known error codes, as it will be filled out by Sentry. For proprietary or vendor-specific error codes, adding these values will give additional information to the user.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Data
member.summary: Arbitrary extra data that might help the user understand the error thrown by this mechanism.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.SentryException.Module
member.summary: The optional module, or package which the exception type lives in.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.SentryException.ThreadId
member.summary: An optional value which refers to a thread in the threads interface.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.SentryException.Mechanism
member.summary: An optional mechanism that created this exception.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.SentryException.Data
member.summary: Arbitrary extra data that related to this error
member.remarks: The protocol does not yet support data at this level. For this reason this property is not serialized. The data is moved to the event level on Extra until such support is added

On some platforms it's not possible to query the CPU frequency. Currently such platforms are iOS and WebGL.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Device.DeviceType
member.summary: Kind of device the application is running on.

members.member:
Unique device identifier. Depends on the running platform.
iOS: UIDevice.identifierForVendor (UUID) Android: The generated Installation ID Windows Store Apps: AdvertisingManager::AdvertisingId (possible fallback to HardwareIdentification::GetPackageSpecificToken().Id) Windows Standalone: hash from the concatenation of strings taken from Computer System Hardware Classes
TODO: Investigate - Do ALL platforms now return a generated installation ID? See https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-java/pull/1455

member.summary: The column number of the call.

member.summary: Source code in filename at line number.

member.summary: A list of source code lines before context_line (in order) – usually [lineno - 5:lineno].

member.summary: A list of source code lines after context_line (in order) – usually [lineno + 1:lineno + 5].

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.InApp
member.summary: Signifies whether this frame is related to the execution of the relevant code in this stacktrace.
member.example: For example, the frames that might power the framework’s web server of your app are probably not relevant, however calls to the framework’s library once you start handling code likely are.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.Vars
member.summary: A mapping of variables which were available within this frame (usually context-locals).

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.FramesOmitted
member.summary: Which frames were omitted, if any.
member.remarks: If the list of frames is large, you can explicitly tell the system that you’ve omitted a range of frames. The frames_omitted must be a single tuple two values: start and end.
member.example: If you only removed the 8th frame, the value would be (8, 9), meaning it started at the 8th frame, and went until the 9th (the number of frames omitted is end-start). The values should be based on a one-index.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.Package
member.summary: The assembly where the code resides.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.Platform
member.summary: This can override the platform for a single frame. Otherwise the platform of the event is assumed.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.ImageAddress
member.summary: Optionally an address of the debug image to reference. If this is set and a known image is defined by debug_meta then symbolication can take place.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.SymbolAddress
member.summary: An optional address that points to a symbol. We actually use the instruction address for symbolication but this can be used to calculate an instruction offset automatically.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.InstructionAddress
member.summary:
An optional instruction address for symbolication.
This should be a string with a hexadecimal number that includes a 0x prefix.
If this is set and a known image is defined in the Debug Meta Interface, then symbolication can take place.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.InstructionOffset
member.remarks: The official docs refer to it as 'The difference between instruction address and symbol address in bytes.' In .NET this means the IL Offset within the assembly.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.AddressMode
member.summary: Optionally changes the addressing mode. The default value is the same as `"abs"` which means absolute referencing. This can also be set to `"rel:DEBUG_ID"` or `"rel:IMAGE_INDEX"` to make addresses relative to an object referenced by debug id or index.

member.name: M:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.ConfigureAppFrame(Sentry.SentryOptions)
member.summary: Configures based on the and or .
member.remarks: will remain with the same value if previously set.

member.name: T:Sentry.SentryStackTrace
member.remarks: A stacktrace contains a list of frames, each with various bits (most optional) describing the context of that frame. Frames should be sorted from oldest to newest.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackTrace.Frames

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.RequestBodyCompressionBuffered
member.summary: Whether the body compression is buffered and the request 'Content-Length' known in advance.
member.remarks: Without reading through the Gzip stream to have its final size, it's no possible to use 'Content-Length' header value. That means 'Content-Encoding: chunked' has to be used which is sometimes not supported. Sentry on-premise without a reverse-proxy, for example, does not support 'chunked' requests.

member.summary: Whether or not to include referenced assemblies in each event sent to sentry. Defaults to .

member.summary: What mode to use for reporting referenced assemblies in each event sent to sentry. Defaults to .

member.summary: What modes to use for event automatic deduplication

member.summary: Path to the root directory used for storing events locally for resilience. If set to null, caching will not be used.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.FileSystem
member.summary: Sets the filesystem instance to use. Defaults to the actual . Used for testing.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.InitCacheFlushTimeout
member.summary: If set to a positive value, Sentry will attempt to flush existing local event cache when initializing. Set to to disable this feature. This option only works if is configured as well.
member.remarks: The trade off here is: Ensure a crash that happens during app start is sent to Sentry even though that might slow down the app start. If set to false, the app might crash too quickly, before Sentry can capture the cached error in the background.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.DefaultTags
member.summary: Defaults tags to add to all events. (These are indexed by Sentry).
member.remarks: If the key already exists in the event, it will not be overwritten by a default tag.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.TracesSampleRate
member.summary: Indicates the percentage of the tracing data that is collected. Setting this to 0 discards all trace data. Setting this to 1.0 collects all trace data. Values outside of this range are invalid. Default value is 0, which means tracing is disabled.
member.remarks: Random sampling rate is only applied to transactions that don't already have a sampling decision set by other means, such as through , by inheriting it from an incoming trace header, or by copying it from .

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.TracesSampler
member.summary: Custom delegate that returns sample rate dynamically for a specific transaction context.
member.remarks: Returning null signals that the sampler did not reach a sampling decision. In such case, if the transaction already has a sampling decision (for example, if it's started from a trace header) that decision is retained. Otherwise sampling decision is determined by applying the static sampling rate set in .

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.StackTraceMode
member.summary: ATTENTION: This option will change how issues are grouped in Sentry!
member.remarks: Sentry groups events by stack traces. If you change this mode and you have thousands of groups, you'll get thousands of new groups. So use this setting with care.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.MaxAttachmentSize
member.summary: Maximum allowed file size of attachments, in bytes. Attachments above this size will be discarded.
member.remarks: Regardless of this setting, attachments are also limited to 20mb (compressed) on Relay.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.DetectStartupTime
member.summary: Whether the SDK should attempt to detect the app's and device's startup time.
member.remarks: Note that the highest precision value relies on which might not be available. For example on Unity's IL2CPP.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.AutoSessionTrackingInterval
member.summary: Determines the duration of time a session can stay paused before it's considered ended.
member.remarks: Note: This interval is only taken into account when integrations support Pause and Resume.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.AutoSessionTracking
member.summary: Whether the SDK should start a session automatically when it's initialized and end the session when it's closed.
member.remarks: Note: this is disabled by default in the current version, but will become enabled by default in the next major version. Currently this only works for release health in client mode (desktop, mobile applications, but not web servers).

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.UseAsyncFileIO
member.summary: Whether the SDK should attempt to use asynchronous file I/O. For example, when reading a file to use as an attachment.
member.remarks: This option should rarely be disabled, but is necessary in some environments such as Unity WebGL.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.CrashedLastRun
member.summary: Delegate which is used to check whether the application crashed during last run.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.KeepAggregateException
member.summary: Keep in sentry logging. The default behaviour is to only log and not include the root . Set KeepAggregateException to true to include the root .

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.NetworkStatusListener
member.summary: Provides a mechanism to convey network status to the caching transport, so that it does not attempt to send cached events to Sentry when the network is offline. Used internally by some integrations. Not intended for public usage.
member.remarks: This must be public because we use it in Sentry.Maui, which can't use InternalsVisibleTo because MAUI assemblies are not strong-named.

member.name: M:Sentry.SentryOptionsExtensions.DisableDuplicateEventDetection(Sentry.SentryOptions)
member.summary: Disables the strategy to detect duplicate events.
member.remarks: In case a second event is being sent out from the same exception, that event will be discarded. It is possible the second event had in fact more data. In which case it'd be ideal to avoid the first event going out in the first place.
member.param: The SentryOptions to remove the processor from.

member.name: M:Sentry.SentryOptionsExtensions.DisableAppDomainUnhandledExceptionCapture(Sentry.SentryOptions)

member.name: M:Sentry.SentrySdk.AddBreadcrumb(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.String},Sentry.BreadcrumbLevel)
member.summary: Adds a breadcrumb to the current Scope.
member.param: If a message is provided it’s rendered as text and the whitespace is preserved. Very long text might be abbreviated in the UI.

Categories are dotted strings that indicate what the crumb is or where it comes from. Typically it’s a module name or a descriptive string. For instance ui.click could be used to indicate that a click happened in the UI or flask could be used to indicate that the event originated in the Flask framework.
The type of breadcrumb. The default type is default which indicates no specific handling. Other types are currently http for HTTP requests and navigation for navigation events.
Data associated with this breadcrumb. Contains a sub-object whose contents depend on the breadcrumb type. Additional parameters that are unsupported by the type are rendered as a key/value table.
